New Records: This 2-1 win over Finland in Helsinki is the first time Ireland have fought back from conceding first to win a competitive game since beating Kazakhstan in October 2013.
This is the first away victory in this competition since it began six years ago.
Key Match Events: Robbie Brady scored an 88th-minute winner following a stunning assist from substitute Festy Ebosele.
Liam Scales scored his first goal for Ireland to cancel out Joel Pohjanpalo’s opener.
Joel Pohjanpalo capitalized on a disastrous Nathan Collins under hit back pass to score for Finland.
Evan Ferguson’s goal was disallowed when a free kick from Brady went out of play and couldn’t be kept in by Collins.
Pre-Game Insights: Part of Ireland’s game plan was to lure the home side out close to the defensive third and then win possession to counter in the areas left exposed by a pair of full backs who ventured forward.
Post-Match Reflections: Heimir Hallgrímsson described the win as a crucial step to allay fears of relegation and halt the 'downward spiral' since he took over.
Hallgrímsson emphasized the need to 'stop the bleeding' and backed up the positive talk and belief in what he can do.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Heavy rain in Helsinki the day before kick-off affected the game conditions.
The attendance for the match was 16,105.
